[h1]Little Nightmares is a masterpiece, but this sequel isn't.[/h1]

[i]TL;DR LN2 kills you too suddenly too often, so players don't get immersed enough to be properly spooked by what you're discovering in the world.[/i]

It is still a good game, especially if you want lore and a challenge, but I have very good reasons for my title statement, so please bear with me and I think you'll agree.

Both Little Nightmares 1 and 2 games are very fun. They both have:
[list]
    [*]Gorgeous 10/10 art direction,
    [*]Beautiful music,
    [*]Phenomenal level design,
    [*]Fantastic lore, etc.
[/list]
But where the two games are vastly different is how [b]sudden and frequent[/b] dying/restarting is in this installment (and honestly some of the first game's DLC as well).

Little Nightmares 2 is incredibly lethal, with insta-death enemies everywhere, insta-kill traps well hidden, and super tight platforming which allows for no mistakes. This is all very challenging and fun, but it is fatally [i]antithetical to capital-h Horror[/i] as a genre.

As it is, Little Nightmares 2 is an [i]action-packed mystery and exploration game[/i]. Such games can be [b]awesome[/b], but that does not make them [b]Horror[/b]. Even if they have spooky looking bad guys, the player doesn't feel that creeping doom and dreadful chill grip your heart while playing them.

[u]Here's my proposed reason why:[/u]

Horror as a genre absolutely requires [b]deep immersion[/b]. You need to lose yourself in the screen, totally forget the room around your monitor, and become one with your character. When making a terrible discovery about the world, you need to be [b]seriously engrossed[/b] to feel the creeping Horror in the depths of your soul.

And unfortunately, the fastest possible way to [b]lose immersion[/b] is to [b]die and start a scene over.[/b]

It is to be reminded it's all a video game suddenly and violently. To re-face the same monster, to be chased down the same hallway, or to re-make the same discovery over and over again, becoming familiar with it and learning to master it. [b]This erases all the tension built up for the scene.[/b]

These things obliterate immersion, and with it, the slithering feeling of Horror like the first game had.

Little Nightmares 1 could be beaten entirely with only a tiny handful of deaths. You had lots of time to be [b]immersed[/b]. When things went wrong, you had room to panic, spot a solution, and fix it [b]before you died[/b].

You stayed in your character's head more, and [b]stayed "in the zone"[/b] to be truly horrified by what was happening around you in The Maw.

Little Nightmares 2 is a bit of a skill-issue grindfest. Every monster moves lightning fast and kills you instantly at longer ranges. Traps delete you if you step one pixel out of line. Chase sequences have zero room for error so you'll always re-do them multiple times, [b]completely destroying any drama the game built up for the chase.[/b] It forces you to win the game through rote memorization, which ruins both immersion and horror (but can still be fun! I want to stress that fact).

While this level of challenge is certainly satisfying in other games, it's a very different genre and "feel" than what Little Nightmares should be, and it suffers for that.

[u]Reasons to play:[/u] 
[list]

[/list]

[hr][/hr] 

[h1] Review [/h1]

In our day and age of bloated RPGs, stale shooters and an overabundance of indie copycats that pinball between either opaque walking simulators or too "on the nose" narrative drivel, Little Nightmares II (and the franchise as a whole) is truly a shining light, a beacon of hope for games as an art form. Little Nightmares II shook me to the core, both as a visceral experience and a cerebral story it delivers an A-game in visual concept and auditive design. Little Nightmares truly embodies the feeling of a movie classic, on the fringes of mainstream but deeply rooted in the sentiment of excellency in the craft. What a story, what a design and what a perfect usage of the medium.

Getting my initial gushing out of the way, Little Nightmares II (LN2) might at first glance come off as a rather cut-and-dried indie platformer but could as a complete piece just as well battle it out with the AAA titles in terms of intriguing yet easy-to-follow storyline, adventurous and thrilling gameplay paired with a distinct visual style. Problem with mainstream appeal when it comes to games is the re-playability aspect. As suspected this isn't a game you can grind, master or in any way quench your competitiveness, neither is it a mastodon practice in versatility and endless possibilities of role-playing. It is a concise game, with a wonderfully presented story and exquisite game mechanics to deliver said story.

LN2 is very similar to the first installment, so if being stale is a worry when picking this game up I can assure you that it blows the first game out of the water with everything the developers have learned and keeps things fresh in terms of level design and cinematography while still not forgetting about the core concept. The only thing that could be argued is if the respective settings suit the style going for better, where the first game delivered the doll-house perspective to a tee through the setting of the fantastical yet intimate The Maw while the second game has "outdoor" acts where the "cutting of the forefront" doesn't benefit the immersion at points (for example, pools of water in a forest that are cut for the viewer in an aquarium sort of way). But I think this is more or less a matter of taste, as the whimsical [b]Spirited Away[/b] feel of the first game is countered with the bleak [b]Blade Runner[/b] or [b]Se7en[/b] reality of the second.

If it's something the Little Nightmares franchise succeed in it is its iconic imagery. Both in literal iconography and setting but of course most prevalent in its character designs which feeds into the gameplay. The long neck of the Teacher that follows your every step, the imminent danger of the Doctor that is ready to snatch you up or just the simple trick of playing into the most mundane features with the terror of a [i]Thin Man[/i]. Most impressive is the combination of characteristics that invoke horror but never disgust and gore such as: porcelain and bullies, mannequins and prostheses, apathy and disfigurement. Little Nightmares nails it all and does so with a beautiful way of setting the tone, creating a world and downright great graphics.

The puzzle platformer aspect of LN2 is killing it, both through innovation and immersion. It never truly challenges you, but more often than not tend to surprise you through it's practicality. This said, the only weak point of LN2 that can in my eyes be claimed is in fact the gameplay, though brilliant in it's simplicity it now and then falls victim to either frustrating trial and error or inconsistent design. The more evident of these being the addition of "battle" with a "weapon" that can be found lying around in a room for you to bash your enemies in the area with. This first comes down to maneuvering the said weapon and more importantly time your swings correctly which will take some deaths to figure out. But then the game present curve balls with some enemies (although identical in appearance) starting to juke your swings making the experience actually unfair on the initial encounter. This did not annoy me that much, but more so the fact that you keep on replaying certain parts because of your own incompetence, which is a shame as it ruins the flow of the game. The more egregious fallacy of the two is instead the matter of punishing level design and inconsistent windows for errors, as in several chase-esque sequences I managed to get caught even though I think I am on the right track. This made me reconsider the choices I've made which ultimately turns out futile as all I needed to do was make a jump at just the right time or make sure I don't bump into a single corner etc. At least two times I thus became stuck as I thought the game wanted me to look for another solution when in fact all I needed to do was perfectly execute said chase sequence.

The sound design and music is perfect, making use of themes from the previous game but buffing them to create an even bigger scope and urgency which really encapsulates the seriousness of the game compared to it's predecessor. The story is one for the ages and further develops the dark world Tarsier has created. The horror is more prevalent in this game than the first and it does have more disturbing imagery and settings, but never hits you with modern jump scare tropes. You always know why or when something is scary, it is just a matter of powering through and stay for the amazing game. I did have my share of chills, but I never felt betrayed or attacked as the developers have created a scary game that isn't an unbearable effort to play. One of the unironically best aspects of the game is the fact that you can hold hands. I never thought such a trivial thing would be so comforting yet immersive. Bravo.

LN2 is a masterpiece, but a somewhat flawed one. With some tweaks here and there I would have hailed this game as the best one I've ever played, but as it stands now, some annoying nuisances stops it from reaching the upper echelons of the game medium. As an experience, it is on par with the best work of cinema, the most captivating of books and my most beloved pieces of music. That is Little Nightmares II.


[b]9/10[/b]

Little Nightmares II is an incredibly well-designed horror platformer.

The gameplay is pure trial and error. You're thrown into this unforgiving and creepy world. You experiment with stuff, interact with the world, and maybe even take some risks. And those approaches either work, or they don't and you die horrifically. This makes perfect sense from a meta-narrative perspective: you essentially play as a character who wants to know how the game world works and how to escape it. There are enemies, living and non-living, and they all want to cause you misery. It's up to you to escape that. Simple yet effective. It's not all perfect though; there are moments where the game becomes punishingly hard which [i]may[/i] feel bit unfair. Difficulty spikes aside, the game is generally quite easy as long as you keep in mind how the world works. There are plenty of checkpoints scattered throughout that even dying isn't really that much of a setback. Alongside the usual collectibles, each level also introduces new gameplay mechanics, used rather effectively.

Graphics are fantastic. The forced 2.5D perspective gives the levels a foreboding sense of mystery that would probably be lost if this was a fully 3D platformer. Each level is densely packed with detail and you'd be surprised just how interactive some objects are, even the ones that you absolutely don't need to use. Many, many scenes are visually striking. I'd even use the word 'cinematic' to describe the best ones.

Sound design is exemplary. True to its name, the game has many creepy moments and the sounds just accentuate those perfectly. Directional audio is utilized exceptionally well, and it's often necessary to follow the sound cues so you can escape an encroaching danger safely.

I don't want to spoil the story at all as it's best to discover it yourself. It has some genuinely disturbing moments that caught me off guard. Over the course of your journey, you may become quite attached to some characters and will feel anxious about their ultimate fate. Achieving that without a single line of spoken dialog is quite a feat. There are enough mysteries and secrets that I'm looking forward to the next game (one can hope we will get that!)

The biggest issue with the game is the occasionally frustrating controls. Because you don't move in a 100% 2D plane, it can sometimes be difficult to 'sense' where you're going to go. This problem can be mildly annoying in case of a failed jump to downright unfair in chase sequences where there is little room for error to begin with. I hope you see why that is a major roadblock in a purely trial and error game. Thankfully it gets better with a controller: analog sticks significantly improve the precision of movement. There's excellent controller rumble support, making you feel every jump, every heartbeat in particularly tense situations. While you [i]can[/i] play this with keyboard & mouse, I don't recommend that for the reasons mentioned. You'll just have a much more pleasant time if you fully stick to a controller.

As long as you can tolerate and familiarize yourself with the controls, LN2 can be quite a ride.

[h1]My rating: 8.5/10.[/h1]

[h3]Mild Jank[/h3]
Mechanically, this is roughly the same game, but bigger. It features more invigorating chases, better graphics, a thicker atmosphere... and some of the old problems, too. The collisions are just as bad, seeing how I got stuck in geometry several times. The controls are still floppy, and with how the sequel keeps handling depth perception, every wooden plank over a bottomless abyss was a bridge too far. I've also encountered a few bugs like screen transitions not working or when the remote refused to turn off the TV in the living room puzzle. If any of this happens to you, don't sweat it. Exit to the main menu and reload a save.

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
Now that we're done with the flaws, look at it! One could have an eyegasm just by observing the stills, but wait till you see things in motion. Whoever designed and animated the game's twitching, twisted monstrosities deserve to be mentioned in the same breath as H.R. Giger and Masahiro Ito. Somewhat realistic and simultaneously stylized environments, bathed in theatrical lighting, arouse curiosity, making you ponder what macabre stories transpired behind the scenes. The overwhelming decadence is portrayed so gorgeously that it may seem like the game romanticizes the collapse. However, it's quick to remind us we're not wading through a whimsical cartoon but a fairy tale of sunless purgatories, forever haunted by a cannibal's lullaby.

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]
[quote]All we had to do, was follow the damn train, CJ![/quote]
The gameplay is involving and challenging, but let's face it, you're mostly dragged around on a leash. The debilitating leash lends itself perfectly, considering that Little Nightmares is a rapid, linear horror experience with the accents shifted from the player's agency to tight set pieces, immersion, and themes. Here, being weak and bound is the whole point. Even that clunky combat, despite its skull-crushing viciousness, is anything but empowering and only amplifies the feeling of impotence. You are everyone's prey and the distorted world itself is your lurking big bad wolf.

I couldn't always foretell when something life-threatening would start, so I never felt completely safe, which is great. The gameplay is almost seamlessly divided into separate sections and comes to solving mostly platforming puzzles at your own leisure, then doing the same with some angry ass abomination on your tail. These thrilling sequences are delivered in short bursts, thank god. Otherwise, my heart would pop from the sense of urgency, the sheer level of engagement, and faulty depth perception that lead to more deaths than I could count.

Stealth is fast-paced and doesn't try your patience or detract from the action for too long. Instead, the difficulty gets manifested in testing your ability to guess the intended route and stick close to it as the only means of survival. Underestimate another indeterminate hitbox, miss a tiny window of opportunity, or let your thumb slip off the stick for a millisecond - and it's over. By design, it's a trial and error sprint, which I have nothing against, considering the generous autosave frequency. You'll never lose more than a few minutes of progress.

I enjoyed the moments of anticipation, stimulating payoffs, as well as the truly nightmarish imagery that got under my skin. I sort of pride myself on being desensitized to everything disturbing, so I began as a skeptic, all up-in-arms with that cheeky "try me" attitude. Before the classroom scene struck me down. The game got me good there, making me irrevocably fall under its dark spell thereon. And then, these mannequins... Condemned has nothing on this. There's so much pleasure in seeing an old trope done right. It was a fun ride.

[h3]Themes[/h3]
[quote]Best days of our short, terrible lives.[/quote]
I deliberately steer away from the word "story" since I'm still not sure if it exists outside of Internet's conspiracy theories. These guys casually make FNAF look as if it had the same level of thought put into it as Mulholland Drive, so they can take a hike. I have nothing against intentionally muddying the waters though, accepting the narrative as an abstraction. All I know is that Little Nightmares 2 is a prequel where instead of obese elites, this time, we have the office middle class and blue collars. Less feasts and cruises, more nooses and the omnipresent TV.

The setting appeals to everything emotional rather than rational. I can feel what they mean by all the casual cruelty, bent reality, Oliver Twist vs. Pinocchios dichotomy, the unsettling prosthetics. The decay, the futility, the brutality of hushing and smothering. I could hear Pink Floyd playing in my head, too. Deep down in my heart, I understand, but I can't begin to interpret the cardinal vibe of this game's surreal ensemble literally. Is it about willpower, twisting the hand of morbidly grimacing fate? Is this how adults get made? Draw your own conclusions, mine are too personal to unholster.

Little Nightmares II is nothing short of breathtaking. It's visuals are gorgeous, it's puzzles clever and it's horror and atmosphere absolutely dripping of dread.

It does practically everything right that a sequel should, upping the mystery of the world, exploring the characters that inhabit it, and definitely ramping up the scares. It's without a doubt one of my absolute favourite horror games, and a lot of it is due to the fact that it never relies on cheap jump-scares but rather builds such an oppressive audio-visual atmosphere that you can't help to hesitate when stepping into a new, often darkened and gloomy, room. The Little Nightmares series captures such a feeling of dread that I haven't really felt since playing Silent Hill 2 for the first time, and I'm not even exaggerating.

The story had me hooked from the very first moment, and I just found myself more and more invested the deeper I went, very similar to the first outing. Having played the original isn't necessary, but it's a great benefit as it fills in a lot of story details and character motives.

As I mentioned earlier, the visuals leave very little to be desired. It has this sense of scale and depth that truly takes your breath away. You feel so small and exposed throughout your journey, and there are plenty of vistas where you can't help but to stop and just stare, taking in the landscapes and horrors spread before you.

A huge part of the presentation is also the audio design and music, and I can't stress enough the benefit of playing this with a good sound setup. Every booming footstep on a floor above you, the creak of a rotting floorboard, and the rasping breaths of the denisens of the dreary places you venture through are superb. Tobias Lilja wrote and produced the soundtrack, and he did an absolutely stupendous job with it, filled with chilling ambience and pounding, oppressive, industrial beats, another part of the games design that reminds me of the best parts of the Silent Hill franchise.

The puzzle sections are often challenging but never unfair, with plenty of clues both in the environment, and cleverly visualized by your AI partner that accompanies you throughout most of your journey. The hints never feel too on-the-nose and leave most of the brain gymnastics up to the player.

My only complaint is that some of the more panic-filled parts, where you need to perhaps outrun a foe, can often feel like trial and error, where the things you are trying to escape from behaves unpredictably, sometimes catching you in an unfair situation where only dying and trying again will get you through. You'll get killed by one move, try again and get past it, just to get killed by a second move moments later. Repeat until you beat the scenario. However, these are very few, there are only 2 or 3 sections that made me feel this way, and the rest is thrilling and heart-pounding from beginning to end.

Overall, I absolutely adore this franchise, and I hope we get to see more of this world in the near future. I'd love some DLC that expands the universe in a similar way as the DLC for the first game did, but it also feels like there's plenty of room, both in the story and in the universe as a whole, for a sequel to continue the web of intrigue that Tarsier Studios have woven.

Nothing is spoon fed to the player, almost everything is up for interpretation, to discover the hidden (or not-so-hidden) meanings behind the game’s happenings. Yet, it is not told in a confusing or obscure manner. I found that it also assisted in conveying the loneliness and somber tone which the developers have seemingly mastered.


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
LN2 features a mix of gameplay, often grouped in different sections, whilst seamlessly switching between each other. Most dominantly, it is a suspense adventure game with platforming, puzzle and stealth elements. Yet, there are various intense (and at times, unforgiving) chase sequences and even action/"fighting" parts. I term the phrase "fighting" lightly as it is by no means the heart of the game, but adds diversity. 

[b] [u]Horror Elements[/u] [/b]
Whilst there are ample titles plastered all over Steam that are labelled "horror", I am certain many  thriller enthusiasts will agree with me when I say that most of the cheap Indies are just not scary. Understandably, this will differ from person to person, and we all have differing ideas of what is "thrilling" or "scary”, but this is where LN2 succeeds. LN2 is a standout title because it understands where most of horror titles go wrong. Atmosphere and tension building. It does not rely on cheap scares or an overabundance of enemies to cause a shock response from the player.  Instead, it builds its immersive universe right from the very beginning and adds to it as the game progresses. LN2's threats are ever evolving, it is never known if you are in a safe area, or not. Events can go from 0-100 extremely quickly and when it is least expected. Chase sequences do not drag on endlessly, they are short and abrupt, keeping players on edge for the entirety of the game. The threats themselves are extremely unnerving, both in their appearance, the way they move and the accompanied excellent sound design. My favourite area was exploring the grungy hospital, but beware of its patients, they will come after you in the darkness, when you're not directly looking at them and when you least expect it.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2731016444

[b] [u]Puzzles[/u] [/b]
LN2 is a linear experience, and I never found its puzzles difficult at all. Majority of the puzzles are platform based. Some examples include pushing something to be able to reach the next area (as the protagonist is very small), find items and display them in the correct order (shown on a nearby template), locate a key by using an X-ray machine to check the innards of nearby toys or traverse portals by following sound. These are just a handful of examples and there are plenty more, but what I appreciated most is that players are never told explicitly what to do, but there is no need for that. The game design was set out remarkably, so this was simply not required. However, if I continuously died in a certain section, or took far longer than intended, sometimes a vague hint would show up such as "Use L toggle to push items".

[b] [u]Action & Save Points[/u] [/b]
There are moments in the game where, unlike many suspenseful horrors, players can and must fight back to survive. Mono can pick up a nearby hammer and slam it down on attacking enemies. However, it must be well timed as generally there is only 1 chance to succeed, if that is missed then it is usually game over. This is not all bad as the game has an extensive auto save system which saves very frequently.

[h1]Visuals & Sound[/h1]
The art in Little Nightmares is gorgeous, in the most morbid way possible. It brilliantly combines a very tiny and innocent little boy into a hideous and devoid world, filled with everything trying to hunt him down. As the protagonist is so small, everything around him looks out of proportion and extremely daunting, even if it is just simple things like a door (which he cannot reach). It is a great metaphor for how he dangerous the world seems around him.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2730284026

As stated previously, there is no dialogue. Yet, the masterful sound design tells its story and is sure to keep players on edge. Often, I heard the enemies before I saw them, and it was enough to make me nervous before I had even entered the room where the anticipated threat was.

[b] Controller Recommended? [/b] Yes
[b]Replayability value:[/b] Yes, many collectable items to find including hats and glitched fragments.


[h1]Bugs & Glitches[/h1]
Unfortunately, I did find myself colliding with objects on a handful of occasions. Especially when trying to sneak by undetected. I often became stuck in objects and could not move, usually resulting in the enemy spotting me. It was also more difficult than it should have been when trying to pick up objects or grasp ledges quickly. Perhaps just a result of slightly clunky controls but it did become frustrating.


[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Little Nightmares 2 is a must play for horror enthusiasts. Its suspense riddled gameplay, cute yet grim visuals and ever-changing game formula make it one of the best horror experiences I have had in a long time. Even describing it is difficult, as it is exceptionally unique and distinctive.  If you like spooky adventure titles with some light puzzles, do yourself a favour and pick this one up.

4. Creatures and puzzles
In 'Little Nightmares 1', the creature has an appearance reminiscent of the old Halloween costume or 'The spirited away'. However, there was a sense that it was not enough to be called a horror game because the proportion of puzzles was too high rather than these creepy creatures.

Even this approach had been used previously in 'Limbo' and 'Inside', with puzzles of inferior quality and completion, so 'Little Nightmares 1' remained in my memory as a disappointing work in many ways.

However, in 'Little Nightmares 2', a homage to monsters that appear in ghost stories and other horror creations raises the charm of the creature to the next level. Slender Man, The Ring, nurse of Silent Hill.

Also they pursued both novelty and fun by using well-structured puzzles and puzzles that cooperate with NPC instead of monotonous and repetitive puzzles.

Players who have played 'Little Nightmares 1' may have found it difficult to understand the story due to its sudden development and poor narrative. In addition, since the DLC developed a side story, it could not fill the lack of explanation of the main story.

In 'Little Nightmares 2' ,the prequel, dealt with and the past of 'Six' and expanded worldview. In addition, there is a problem in that the 'movement hitting the wall' and the 'motion interacting with the object' collide, so that the proper operation is not performed. More precisely, the linkage between motions is unnatural. This causes unintended inconvenience in many action scenes.


6-3) Checkpoint problem
In order to get Collectible, you may have to endure the inconvenience of having to complete all chapters. If you're very unlucky, you may have to replay the entire game. Comparing this with Limbo and Inside's checkpoint system, I can tell that it is a really poor system.

However, auto save except the collectible is really well-set-up.


6-4) Safe location
Another problem is that the enemy's detection system works strangely unless you are located in a 'specific location' in a chase or hide-and-seek scene. Even if you hide properly in visual, enemy can see through wall and find you because you are located in wrong position which is 1mm away from safe location.

I'm not criticizing the difficulty became harder. However, in some sections, it was set not to tolerate even single mistake, so it was a level that felt unreasonable rather than difficult.

Repeated trial and error causes frustration rather than fear, and it prevents immersion in the game, so I think it is necessary to relax the baseline for achieving the goal a little.
